name: Range from a list of data

skills.name: Order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number
Calculate the range from a list of data
Solve missing number problems involving the range

explanations.A: The range is the biggest number subtract the smallest number, which is 17 ‚Äì 2 = 15
explanations.B: Not quite. We use the biggest and the smallest number to find the range
explanations.C: Be careful, 2 is the mode not the range. Remember the range is a measure of spread it is not an average.
explanations.D: Not quite. You have identified the right numbers to use but have found the total not the difference.

explanations.D: The range is the biggest number subtract the smallest number, which is 17 ‚Äì (‚Äì10) = 17 + 10 = 27

explanations.A: Be careful. 5 is the mode not the range. Remember the range is a measure of spread it is not an average.
explanations.B: Not quite. You have identified the right numbers to use but have added rather than subtracted.
explanations.C: The range is the biggest number subtract the smallest number, which is 17 ‚Äì (‚Äì6) = 17 + 6 = 23
explanations.D: Be careful. We must take the signs into account. -6 is the smallest number not 1.

explanations.A: Almost! You're right that y has to be 10 or smaller. But what's the lowest value it could be?
explanations.B: Almost! You're right that y has to be 3 or larger. But what's the highest value it could be?
explanations.C: So close! You have all the right numbers but look closely at your inequality signs. What does 10 ‚â§ y mean? What does y ‚â§ 3 mean? Can y be both of these things at once?
explanations.D: Ignoring ùë¶, the range of the numbers is 10 ‚Äì 3 = 7. This is the range we want. This means y needs to be less than or equal to 10 (y ‚â§ 10) as if it was larger the range would change. This also means y needs to be greater than or equal to 3 (y ‚â• 3) as if it was smaller the range would change. We can write in one go as 3 ‚â§ y ‚â§ 10.

explanations.A: So close! You have all the right numbers but look closely at your inequality signs. What does 11 ‚â§ y mean? What does y ‚â§ 3 mean? Can y be both of these things at once?
explanations.B: Ignoring ùë¶, the range of the numbers is 11 ‚Äì 3 = 8. This is the range we want. This means y needs to be less than or equal to 11 (y ‚â§ 11) as if it was larger the range would change. This also means y needs to be greater than or equal to 3 (y ‚â• 3) as if it was smaller the range would change. We can write in one go as 3 ‚â§ y ‚â§ 11.
explanations.C: Almost! You're right that y has to be 3 or larger. But what's the highest value it could be?
explanations.D: Almost! You're right that y has to be 11 or smaller. But what's the lowest value it could be?

explanations.B: Not quite. We use the biggest and the smallest number to find the range. A place value chart will help you order these numbers.

explanations.D: Not quite. Check your working. Remember to line up your digits with the same place value before subtracting.

explanations.A: Be careful. These numbers are not listed in size order. Remember to use common denominators when comparing the size of fractions.
explanations.B: Be careful. We use the largest and smallest number to calculate the range. Remember to use common denominators when comparing the size of fractions.
explanations.C: Be careful. These numbers are not listed in size order. Remember to use common denominators when comparing the size of fractions.
explanations.D: The largest fraction is 5/9 and the smallest is 3/7, and so the range is 5/9 ‚Äì 3/7
